programFocus: Power-Endurance for Elite Sport Climbing (5.14+ Focus)
programDescripton: This 16-week program is designed for an elite sport climber aiming to push their redpoint grade. It follows a periodized structure, starting with a foundation of strength and power, transitioning into sport-specific power-endurance, and culminating in a performance phase dedicated to redpointing a goal project. The program is built for 3-4 sessions per week to accommodate a busy schedule, emphasizing high-quality, focused training over sheer volume.

programNotes.safetyDisclaimer: Always consult with a healthcare professional before beginning any new training program. The loads and intensities described are for an elite-level athlete and should be adjusted based on your body's feedback. Pay close attention to your fingers, elbows, and shoulders. Do not train through sharp or persistent pain.
programNotes.injuryModifications: No injuries were reported. However, given the high intensity of this program, it is crucial to proactively manage recovery and listen to your body. If pain develops, especially in soft tissues, reduce intensity, take extra rest, and consult a qualified physical therapist.
programNotes.assumptionsMade: This program assumes you have access to a commercial climbing gym with extensive bouldering, sport climbing routes, a spray wall, a fingerboard, and a standard set of strength training equipment (e.g., free weights, pull-up bars). It also assumes that due to your stated time constraints (family and full-time job), each session should be highly focused and completed within approximately 2-2.5 hours. The weekly schedule is a template (Mon/Wed/Fri); adjust the days to fit your personal schedule, but ensure at least one full rest day between high-intensity sessions.

weeklySchedule.weeklyFocus: Build foundational max strength and power. Focus on high-quality attempts on limit-level boulders and supplemental strength exercises. Prioritize perfect form and full recovery between attempts.

exercises.details: Light rowing or cycling to elevate heart rate.
exercises.howToAdjust: Adjust duration based on how you feel.

exercises.details: Perform controlled movements: arm circles, leg swings, hip circles, cat-cow, thoracic spine rotations.
exercises.howToAdjust: Focus on areas that feel particularly tight.

exercises.details: Climb 10-15 easy boulder problems, focusing on precise movement and fluid motion. Gradually increase difficulty from V0 to V5.
exercises.howToAdjust: Climb fewer problems if short on time, but ensure you feel warm and activated.

exercises.details: Select 1-2 boulder problems at or slightly above your redpoint grade (V11+). Work the individual moves and short links. The goal is recruitment, not sending.
exercises.reps: Focus on 5-8 high-quality attempts on crux moves.
exercises.howToAdjust: If a move feels impossible, find a slightly easier but similar problem. If it feels too easy, find a harder project.

exercises.details: Use a weight that makes 3-5 reps challenging but possible with good form (no kipping).
exercises.howToAdjust: Increase weight if you can do more than 5 reps. Decrease weight if form breaks down.

exercises.details: From a dead hang, raise your legs as high as possible while keeping them straight. Control the negative.
exercises.howToAdjust: Easier: Bend your knees. Harder: Perform toes-to-bar raises.

activities.details: Easy cycling or walking to flush lactic acid.
Hold stretches for major muscle groups: forearms (flexors/extensors), lats, chest, shoulders, and hips.
activities.howToAdjust: Ease into the stretch; it should not be painful.

exercises.details: 5 mins of rowing followed by dynamic stretches (arm/leg swings, torso twists).
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb 8-10 problems, starting very easy and building to your onsight grade (V9). Focus on movement quality.
exercises.howToAdjust: Spend more time on the harder end of the warm-up to prepare for the main session.

exercises.details: Climb 6-8 different boulder problems in the V9-V10 range. These should be challenging but doable within 2-4 attempts.
exercises.howToAdjust: If you can't send in 4 attempts, lower the grade. If sending first-try, increase the grade.

exercises.details: Standing or seated, press dumbbells overhead until arms are fully extended. Maintain a stable core.
exercises.howToAdjust: Adjust weight to hit the target rep range with good form.

exercises.details: Standard push-ups with a focus on full range of motion.
exercises.howToAdjust: Harder: Elevate feet. Easier: Perform on knees.

activities.details: Very easy bouldering (V0-V1) or light cycling.
Hold stretches for forearms, lats, chest, shoulders.

exercises.details: 5 mins of light jogging or cycling, followed by dynamic stretches focusing on hips and shoulders.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Traverse on a large, easy-angled wall, focusing on smooth transitions and footwork.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb continuously on easy terrain (5.9-5.10d) without getting pumped. The goal is to stay just below your aerobic threshold. You should be able to hold a conversation. Downclimb or traverse as needed.
exercises.requiredEquipment: Sport climbing wall or large bouldering wall
exercises.howToAdjust: If you get pumped, choose easier terrain. If it feels too easy and your heart rate is very low, find slightly more continuous or steeper terrain.

activities.details: A comprehensive stretching routine covering all major muscle groups: neck, shoulders, chest, back, forearms, hips, quads, hamstrings, calves.

weeklySchedule.weeklyFocus: Introduce power-endurance work. Translate strength gains into the ability to perform multiple hard moves consecutively. Maintain top-end strength with a smaller dose of limit bouldering.

exercises.details: 5 mins rowing, 5 mins dynamic stretches (focus on hips/shoulders).
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb on a spray wall, making up progressively harder sequences of 5-8 moves. Build up to V7-V8 intensity.
exercises.howToAdjust: Focus on moves that mimic your project style.

exercises.details: Create and climb a 15-20 move boulder circuit on a spray wall or steep board. The difficulty should be around 5.13b/c. The goal is to complete the circuit.
exercises.requiredEquipment: Spray wall or steep bouldering wall
exercises.howToAdjust: Harder: Add more moves, use smaller holds, or reduce rest. Easier: Break the circuit into two halves or use better holds.

exercises.details: Cycle through front plank, left side plank, and right side plank without rest.
exercises.howToAdjust: Harder: Add weight to your back or lift a limb. Easier: Reduce hold time to 30-45 seconds.

activities.details: 5 mins easy cycling, followed by 10 mins of static stretching for forearms, lats, and shoulders.

exercises.details: 5 mins rowing, 5 mins dynamic stretches.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb 8-10 problems from V0 up to V9.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Work on your limit project from the previous phase for a short duration to maintain max power.
exercises.howToAdjust: Keep this short and focused; it's a supplement, not the main goal of this phase.

exercises.details: Use the same weight and rep scheme as the Strength Phase to maintain strength.
exercises.howToAdjust: Do not increase the weight from the previous phase; the goal is maintenance.

exercises.details: Standard barbell bench press to work antagonist pushing muscles.
exercises.howToAdjust: Adjust weight to hit the target rep range with good form.

exercises.details: Using a cable machine or resistance bands, pull the rope towards your face, retracting your scapula.
exercises.howToAdjust: Focus on the squeeze between your shoulder blades.

activities.details: Hold stretches for chest, lats, shoulders, and forearms.

exercises.details: 5 mins cycling, 5 mins dynamic stretches.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb 2-3 easy routes, building in grade from ~5.10 to ~5.11c.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Select a route at or just below your onsight grade (5.12c/d). Climb it 3 times, with the goal of improving your efficiency and decreasing pump on each burn. Rest fully between burns.
exercises.howToAdjust: If the route is too hard, choose an easier one. If it feels too easy, find a slightly harder route or try to link it into an easier route afterwards.

activities.details: 5 mins easy walking/cycling, followed by 10 mins of full-body static stretching.

weeklySchedule.weeklyFocus: Begin shifting towards performance. Decrease overall training volume and increase intensity on specific route-based objectives. Simulate redpoint burns on hard routes to prepare for the final projecting phase.

exercises.details: 5 mins rowing, 10 mins comprehensive dynamic stretching routine.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb 2 easy routes (5.10, 5.11). Then, move to a project-level route (5.13d-5.14a) and work the moves individually, finishing with one clean ascent of the first half.
exercises.howToAdjust: Your warm-up should be specific to the day's goal. Feel out the holds and moves on your target route.

exercises.details: Select a route that could be a potential project (e.g., a hard 5.13d or a doable 5.14a). After warming up and working the moves, give 2-3 true redpoint attempts from the ground with the intention to send.
exercises.howToAdjust: The goal is to simulate a real performance. If you send, great! If not, analyze why (e.g., pump, power, beta error) and take notes. Do not add more attempts; quality over quantity.

activities.details: 5 mins of very light bouldering (V0), followed by 10 mins of gentle static stretching for key areas.

exercises.details: 10 minutes of light cardio and dynamic movement.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb a few easy problems (V0-V5) to get the body moving.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: A very short, low-volume bouldering session. Climb 3-4 problems at your onsight grade (V9) to maintain recruitment without causing fatigue.
exercises.howToAdjust: The goal is to feel powerful and sharp. Stop before you feel any fatigue.

exercises.details: Standard push-ups.
exercises.howToAdjust: This is for maintenance and posture.

exercises.details: Choose one core exercise (e.g., Hanging Leg Raises) and perform it with high quality.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

activities.details: Gentle stretching for chest and shoulders.

exercises.details: Easy cycling or walking.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb for 20-25 minutes on very easy terrain (5.8-5.9) with zero pump. This is purely for blood flow and recovery.
exercises.howToAdjust: If you feel at all tired, stop. This session is optional and can be replaced with a full rest day.

exercises.details: Spend time on foam rolling your lats, back, and legs. Follow with a comprehensive mobility routine for hips and shoulders.
exercises.howToAdjust: Focus on areas of tightness or soreness from the week's training.

activities.details: Lie on your back and perform diaphragmatic breathing to promote relaxation.

weeklySchedule.weeklyFocus: Full focus on sending a specific project. All sessions are structured around maximizing performance on that climb. Minimal supplemental training; prioritize rest and high-quality attempts.

exercises.details: 10 mins light cardio. 10 mins dynamic stretching & mobility.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb two easy routes (e.g., 5.10d, 5.11c). Then, climb one harder route (~5.12c). Finally, do one hang on the crux holds of your project and rehearse the crux move 1-2 times.
exercises.howToAdjust: This warm-up is highly specific. The goal is to arrive at the base of your project feeling 100% ready to perform, but not at all tired.

exercises.details: Give a maximum of 2-3 high-quality redpoint burns on your main project. Rest completely between attempts. Visualize success and execute your beta perfectly. This is a performance, not a training session.
exercises.howToAdjust: If the first attempt feels terrible, consider using the rest of the session to work on links and save the next true attempt for another day. If you send, celebrate!

activities.details: Very light static stretching for antagonist muscles (chest, triceps) and light mobility work for hips.
activities.howToAdjust: Avoid stretching climbing muscles to exhaustion.

exercises.details: A brisk walk, light jog, or cycling session.
exercises.howToAdjust: The goal is blood flow, not a workout.

exercises.details: Focus on lats, thoracic spine, and hips.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: 10 mins light cardio. 10 mins dynamic stretching & mobility.
exercises.howToAdjust: N/A

exercises.details: Climb two easy routes (e.g., 5.10d, 5.11c). Then, climb one harder route (~5.12c). Finally, do one hang on the crux holds of your project and rehearse the crux move 1-2 times.
exercises.howToAdjust: This should be an identical ritual to the first projecting day of the week.

exercises.details: Second opportunity of the week for redpoint burns. Give a maximum of 2-3 high-quality attempts. Trust your training and execute.
exercises.howToAdjust: Listen to your body. If you feel significantly more fatigued than the first session, it may be better to stop and rest rather than build fatigue for the following week.

activities.details: Very light static stretching for antagonist muscles (chest, triceps) and light mobility work for hips.
activities.howToAdjust: Avoid stretching climbing muscles to exhaustion.

glossary.RPE: Rate of Perceived Exertion, a scale from 1 (rest) to 10 (maximal effort). Used to gauge intensity subjectively.
glossary.Limit Bouldering: Trying boulder problems at your maximum physical limit (V11+) to increase strength and neural recruitment. Sending is not the primary goal; high-quality effort on individual moves is.
glossary.Linked Boulder Circuits: A power-endurance drill where you connect multiple boulder problems or a long sequence of moves on a spray wall to simulate the continuous difficulty of a hard sport route.
glossary.ARC: Aerobic Restoration and Capillarity. Climbing continuously on easy terrain for an extended period (20-45 minutes) at a very low intensity to build a deep endurance base and promote recovery.
